On the other forum where I am a member of, there are a variety of options available to interact with what a forum user has posed. There are likes, love, sad, haha, no, yes, thanks and maybe a few other things (the other forum is down at the moment, so I cannot be more precise and list all of them). Regardless of what is clicked in response to a post, every interaction using those are counted as a reaction to the post. An example would be this post here could get three "like" and three "no" interactions. The forum software, as it was explained on that forum long ago, will add +6 to the reputation counter. Once any sort of interaction is recorded, it is counted and no amount of "no" responses or "sad" responses would be able to lower the reputation of the poster.   

They are using the same forum software as this one.

If one were to add a "-rep" to the existing "+rep" function, at least the reputation counter might serve some purpose. But counting "dislike" reactions the same as "like"? What would be the point?  

I thought rep might serve as a guide to how reputable a member is (i.e the concept it is named for), and therefore how likely to be useful a post is, but we seem to have been diverging from this into "random meaningless forum cookie" territory for some time... How about we just do away with it altogether, and stop showing a pointless and misleading "reaction counter" on every profile?
